study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential role of Citrulline in improving NO bioavailability and exercise performance in older adults.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that Citrulline, as a substrate for NO production, may help mitigate age-related declines in physiological function and exercise performance, though evidence is summarized rather than directly reported.
population_specificity: Older adults, including sedentary individuals and those engaged in competitive sports.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether L-citrulline supplementation improves endothelial function, reduces aortic stiffness, and lowers blood pressure in hypertensive postmenopausal women.
results_summary: L-citrulline supplementation increased L-arginine levels and improved endothelial function (measured by FMD), while also reducing aortic diastolic blood pressure and mean arterial pressure. Aortic stiffness (cfPWV) showed a non-significant decrease.
population_specificity: Hypertensive postmenopausal women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between obesity, sex, and their interaction on whole-body arginine and citrulline metabolism.
results_summary: The study found lower plasma citrulline concentrations in obese individuals but no differences in whole-body production of citrulline. Obesity was associated with overproduction of nitric oxide but lower de novo arginine production.
population_specificity: 83 nonobese (BMI <30) and 80 morbidly obese (BMI >30) middle-aged individuals (40% males).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of short-term inorganic nitrate (NaNO3) supplementation on plasma amino acids, including citrulline, and oxidative stress in healthy young men.
results_summary: The study found that nitrate administration increased plasma citrulline and ornithine concentrations by 16% compared to placebo, suggesting an impact on amino-acid metabolism. No significant changes in oxidative stress markers were observed.
population_specificity: Healthy young men (n = 17 total, 8 in NaNO3 group, 9 in placebo group).
effective_dosage: 0.1 mmol/kg body weight/day of NaNO3 or NaCl (placebo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether watermelon supplementation (rich in L-citrulline) improves exercise performance, muscle oxygenation, and vessel diameter in resistance-trained men.
results_summary: The study found no significant enhancement in isometric force production, bench press performance, blood vessel diameter, or muscle oxygenation with watermelon supplementation compared to placebo, except for a minor increase in skeletal muscle oxygenation during exercise.
population_specificity: 15 resistance-trained men (22.4 ± 2.9 years; 177.5 ± 7.1 cm; 82.7 ± 11.2 kg).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 8-day supplementation with L-citrulline or L-arginine would improve 200 m and 100 m freestyle swimming performance in trained/developmental swimmers and triathletes.
results_summary: The study found no significant improvement in swimming performance (200 m or 100 m time-trials) or plasma nitric oxide levels with L-citrulline or L-arginine supplementation compared to placebo. Blood lactate concentrations increased over time but showed no interaction with supplementation.
population_specificity: 15 trained/developmental swimmers and triathletes (5 females).
effective_dosage: 8 g daily of L-citrulline or L-arginine.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of an amino acid combination containing L-citrulline-malate on muscle perfusion and related dynamics in athletes, using contrast-enhanced ultrasound (CEUS) for quantification.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in biceps perfusion, caliber, or muscle pump between the amino acid combination (including citrulline), green tea extract, and placebo. However, post-exercise muscle perfusion correlated with muscle pump and caliber increases.
population_specificity: 30 young male athletes (24 ± 4 years) regularly practicing resistance training.
effective_dosage: 8 g of L-citrulline-malate (combined with 3 g of L-arginine-hydrochloride).
study_duration: Not specified (crossover trial with single ingestion).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether acute L-citrulline supplementation affects inspiratory muscle oxygenation and respiratory performance in healthy males.
results_summary: The study compared L-citrulline and placebo effects on pulmonary function, maximal inspiratory pressure, and fractional exhaled nitric oxide, but the abstract does not specify the outcomes.
population_specificity: Twelve healthy males

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of foods containing L-citrulline on endurance exercise performance, specifically its potential to enhance nitric oxide bioavailability.
results_summary: The study found no significant effect on exercise performance following consumption of foods rich in L-citrulline (SMD=-0.03, p=0.24). Only three studies on L-citrulline were included, indicating limited evidence.
population_specificity: Endurance exercise participants (specific demographics not detailed for L-citrulline subgroup).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of citrulline malate (CM) as an ergogenic aid for exercise performance and recovery, focusing on its mechanisms and effectiveness.
results_summary: The study found mixed results regarding CM's effectiveness in improving exercise performance, with discrepancies attributed to methodological differences, dosing strategies, and quality control issues. Potential mechanisms include enhanced blood flow, ammonia homeostasis, and ATP production, but conclusive evidence is lacking.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely healthy adults engaged in resistance or high-intensity exercise).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the acute effects of citrulline-malate supplementation on lower-body isokinetic performance in recreationally active women during menstruation.
results_summary: CM significantly increased total work completed during a 5-repetition leg extension protocol but showed no ergogenic benefit during a 50-repetition protocol. No significant differences were found in peak torque production between CM and placebo trials.
population_specificity: Recreationally active women (n=19, aged 23.5 ± 3.1 years) during the menstruating portion of the follicular phase of their menstrual cycle.
effective_dosage: 8 g CM + 12 g dextrose, single dose.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Citrulline malate (CitMal) supplementation prior to strength training increases the number of repetitions performed before voluntary muscular failure.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found a small but statistically significant increase in repetitions (6.4%) with CitMal compared to placebo, particularly for lower body exercises (8.1%), though the effect was modest and not significant for upper body exercises.
population_specificity: Strength-trained men (n = 101), women (n = 26), and untrained men (n = 9).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of citrulline malate supplementation on muscle strength outcomes in resistance-trained individuals through a systematic review and meta-analysis.
results_summary: The meta-analysis of four studies found no overall effect favoring citrulline malate supplementation on muscle strength compared to placebo. The results suggest that citrulline malate may not significantly enhance muscle strength in resistance-trained individuals.
population_specificity: Resistance-trained adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if L-citrulline, a supplement believed to promote vasodilation, could enhance lactate turnover and recovery during high-intensity exercise.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding Citrulline's effects, only stating the study's purpose to clarify its role in lactate removal.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether acute l-Citrulline (CIT) ingestion could attenuate aortic systolic blood pressure (SBP) and leg hemodynamic responses during exercise and cold pressor test (CPT) in hypertensive postmenopausal women.
results_summary: CIT supplementation significantly reduced brachial and aortic SBP responses to combined exercise and CPT compared to placebo, but did not affect femoral artery blood flow, vascular conductance, or functional sympatholysis.
population_specificity: Hypertensive postmenopausal women (aged 61 ± 7 years).
study_duration: Acute (single ingestion with a minimum 3-day washout between conditions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether citrulline, produced via arginine metabolism by certain streptococci, could increase dental plaque pH and suppress caries-causing bacteria.
results_summary: The study found that citrulline synthesis by ADS-positive streptococci increased environmental pH and suppressed ADS-negative bacteria, reducing caries incidence. Clinical use of arginine-containing toothpaste decreased DMFS by 10-20%.
population_specificity: Dental plaque microbiota and clinical dental caries patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of citrulline supplements on post-exercise rating of perceived exertion (RPE), muscle soreness, and blood lactate levels.
results_summary: Citrulline supplementation significantly reduced RPE and muscle soreness 24-h and 48-h post-exercise but did not significantly reduce muscle soreness 72-h post-exercise or lower blood lactate levels.
population_specificity: Healthy individuals
effective_dosage: Most frequent dosage was 8 g of citrulline malate

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether prenatal amino acid supplementation, particularly from the arginine family (including Citrulline), could promote healthy fetal growth.
results_summary: The meta-analysis indicated beneficial effects of arginine family amino acids, including Citrulline, on fetal/birth weight, with arginine itself being the most studied.
population_specificity: Pregnant humans and animals (22 human and 89 animal studies included).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining L-citrulline supplementation with exercise training enhances its vascular and muscular benefits in older adults.
results_summary: The abstract suggests L-citrulline may improve vascular function and muscle protein synthesis, with potential synergistic effects when combined with exercise, but specific results are not detailed.
population_specificity: Older adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chronic nitrate and citrulline supplementation enhances exercise training adaptations, particularly vascular function and exercise performance, in healthy young individuals.
results_summary: The study found that nitrate and citrulline supplementation significantly improved maximal knee extensor strength and showed a trend toward increased knee extensor endurance, but had no effect on vascular function, muscle/cerebral oxygenation, or maximal aerobic performance.
population_specificity: 24 healthy young individuals (12 females).
effective_dosage: 6 g citrulline daily (combined with 520 mg nitrate).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if pre-operative L-arginine/L-citrulline supplementation improves the plasma L-arginine/ADMA ratio and reduces perioperative cardiovascular risk.
results_summary: L-arginine/L-citrulline supplementation increased plasma L-arginine levels and improved the L-arginine/ADMA ratio, with a non-significant trend toward fewer cardiovascular events in high-ADMA patients. ADMA was identified as a predictor of perioperative cardiovascular complications.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing major abdominal and/or thoracic surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of citrulline supplementation on oxidative stress and serum nitrite/nitrate (NOx) levels in patients with type 2 diabetes (T2DM).
results_summary: Citrulline supplementation significantly reduced fasting blood sugar (FBS) and malondialdehyde (MDA) levels while increasing total antioxidant capacity (TAC), citrulline, and NOx levels. No significant changes were observed in glutathione peroxidase (GPx), superoxide dismutase (SOD), body mass index, or energy intake.
population_specificity: 54 patients with type 2 diabetes from specialized clinics of Tabriz University of Medical Sciences.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the acute effects of Citrulline-malate supplementation on aerobic and anaerobic cycling performance in recreationally active males.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results, but it indicates that the study investigated CM's effects on aerobic and anaerobic biking performance, which were previously under-researched.
population_specificity: Recreationally active males

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chronic supplementation with L-citrulline improves endurance cycling performance in trained athletes.
results_summary: Citrulline supplementation improved 40-km time trial performance by 5.2% (trending toward significance) and increased average heart rate, perceived exertion, and power output, but did not prevent fatigue during a supramaximal sprint repeat task.
population_specificity: Nine trained male cyclists (24 ± 3 years; 181 ± 7 cm; 76 ± 13 kg; 4.18 ± 0.51 L·min V[Combining Dot Above]O2max).

study_goal: To evaluate the potential of Citrulline supplementation, with or without exercise, on muscle function and physical performance in adults aged 50 and older.
results_summary: Five of six studies reported benefits of Citrulline on muscle mass, four noted improvements in muscle strength (especially when combined with exercise), and three observed enhanced physical performance, particularly walking speed when combined with exercise.
population_specificity: Adults aged 50 and older, including frail elderly (malnourished, hypertensive, obese, dynapenic-obese).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of different forms of zinc supplementation on plasma citrulline levels as a biomarker of environmental enteric dysfunction (EED) in young children.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in plasma citrulline concentrations among the intervention groups at the end of the trial, suggesting that zinc supplementation did not affect citrulline levels as a biomarker of EED.
population_specificity: Young Laotian children aged 6-23 months with a high prevalence of stunting and zinc deficiency.
effective_dosage: Not specified for citrulline (study focused on zinc supplementation: 7 mg/day, 10 mg/day, or 20 mg/day for 10 days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether L-citrulline supplementation during different menstrual cycle phases affects vasodilator kinetics during muscle contraction in young healthy women.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in vasodilator response amplitude or kinetics between CIT and placebo, regardless of menstrual cycle phase, though vasodilator kinetics were slower during the luteal phase compared to the follicular phase.
population_specificity: 24 young healthy women (13 in the follicular phase, 11 in the luteal phase).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the post-exercise hypotension responsiveness following acute citrulline supplementation in hypertensive individuals.
results_summary: The study found that citrulline malate supplementation increased post-exercise hypotensive effects in hypertensives, with no "non-responders" in the exercise/citrulline group for certain blood pressure measures. The effects were large for diastolic blood pressure across awake, asleep, and 24-hour periods.
population_specificity: Hypertensive individuals
effective_dosage: 6 grams of citrulline malate (acute single dose)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the role of endogenous citrulline production on protein homeostasis, particularly its indirect effects through endothelial and immune function.
results_summary: The study suggests that citrulline may play a key role in regulating endothelial and immune functions, potentially improving organ perfusion and amino acid supply, and indirectly influencing protein metabolism. However, no direct evidence links endogenous citrulline production to protein homeostasis.
population_specificity: Malnourished rodents and humans (general population not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chronic nitric oxide precursor supplementation (including citrulline) improves vascular function and exercise performance in healthy older adults.
results_summary: Citrulline supplementation (combined with nitrate) reduced resting blood pressure and improved cycling performance by enhancing cardiorespiratory responses, but did not affect knee extension performance or other vascular function parameters.
population_specificity: Healthy older adults aged 60-70 years (12 females, 12 males).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether oral administration of l-citrulline (Cit) could effectively reduce blood pressure by increasing nitric oxide (NO) production.
results_summary: Citrulline was found to increase plasma arginine levels more effectively than l-arginine, likely due to lower first-pass metabolism. The antihypertensive effects of Cit were estimated to be in the range of 4.1/2.08 to 7.54/3.77 mmHg, though the exact mechanism remains unclear.
population_specificity: Human and animal studies (not specified in detail).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of L-arginine or L-citrulline supplementation to improve placental vascular development and birth outcomes in resource-constrained settings.
results_summary: The study found that L-arginine supplementation improved maternal and fetal hemodynamics, prevented pre-eclampsia, and led to better birth outcomes, such as higher birth weight and longer gestation. Existing evidence suggests these benefits could extend to low-resource settings, particularly for pregnant women at risk of malaria.
population_specificity: Pregnant women, especially in low-resource settings with high rates of adverse birth outcomes and malaria risk.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the combination of oral L-citrulline and L-arginine improves 10-minute cycling performance and subjective perception of exertion in male soccer players.
results_summary: The study found that Cit + Arg significantly increased power output, plasma NOx, Cit, and Arg levels, and improved subjective perceptions of leg muscle soreness and ease of pedaling compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Male collegiate soccer players (n=24).
effective_dosage: 1.2 g/day each of Cit and Arg for 6 days, with an additional dose 1 hour before testing on day 7.
study_duration: 7 days (6 days of supplementation + testing on day 7).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether citrulline supplementation impacts whole-body protein metabolism in patients with short bowel syndrome (SBS).
results_summary: Citrulline supplementation significantly increased plasma citrulline and arginine levels but did not show an anabolic effect on whole-body protein metabolism in SBS patients with near-normal nutritional status. Further research is needed to assess its impact in severely malnourished SBS patients.
population_specificity: Nine adults with non-malignant short bowel syndrome (residual small bowel 90 ± 48 cm) in near-normal nutritional status, long after surgery.
study_duration: 7 days per supplementation period, with a 13-day washout between regimens.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether acute supplementation with 8 g of citrulline malate (CM) improves anaerobic performance in recreationally active individuals.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in anaerobic performance (repetitions, peak forces) between CM and placebo groups. However, CM supplementation resulted in significantly higher muscle soreness over 72 hours without increased workload.
population_specificity: Recreationally active men and women
effective_dosage: 8 g of citrulline malate (1.11:1 ratio), acute dose

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of L-citrulline supplementation on blood pressure through a systematic review and meta-analysis of human clinical trials.
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of L-citrulline supplementation on brachial or aortic systolic and diastolic blood pressure. Participants' body weight status was identified as a source of heterogeneity among the studies.
population_specificity: Human clinical trial participants (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore whether citrulline, by supporting placental nitric oxide production, could aid proper placentation and prevent placental hypoxia in preeclampsia.
results_summary: The study suggests citrulline may help alleviate the pathogenic impact of excessive sFlt-1 in preeclampsia by supporting nitric oxide production, potentially improving placentation and reducing hypoxia. Rodent studies indicate prenatal supplementation might also lower hypertension risk in adult offspring.
population_specificity: Pregnant women (primarily in the context of preeclampsia prevention) and rodent models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of GSH + L-citrulline or L-citrulline-malate supplementation during resistance training on lean mass and muscle strength, as well as assess safety via clinical chemistry markers.
results_summary: GSH + L-citrulline increased lean mass after 4 weeks compared to placebo, with a positive correlation to muscle strength, but no significant differences were observed after 8 weeks. No adverse effects on blood clinical chemistry variables were noted.
population_specificity: 75 resistance-trained males

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how vitamin D supplementation affects metabolomic profiles, including citrulline, in metabolically healthy and unhealthy obese individuals.
results_summary: Citrulline was significantly altered after vitamin D supplementation in metabolically unhealthy obese individuals, with changes linked to cardiometabolic biomarkers. The effect was phenotype-specific, suggesting differential metabolic responses.
population_specificity: Adults with obesity (metabolically healthy and unhealthy phenotypes) from Tehran province.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of taurine supplementation on growth in low birth weight infants, including its impact on plasma amino acids like citrulline.
results_summary: The study found that taurine supplementation had little or no significant effect on plasma citrulline levels or other growth parameters in low birth weight infants.
population_specificity: Low birth weight infants (LBW)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to establish genotype-phenotype correlations in citrin deficiency and evaluate the effectiveness of arginine supplementation in managing hyperammonemia and neuropsychiatric symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that arginine supplementation, along with diet modification and sodium benzoate, effectively managed hyperammonemia and neuropsychiatric symptoms in a patient with citrin deficiency. It also identified common mutations associated with citrin deficiency and their correlations with clinical and biochemical markers.
population_specificity: A 13-year-old boy with citrin deficiency and a review of 79 cases from 24 studies worldwide.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Citrulline supplementation improves oxygen uptake kinetics during walking in older and young adults.
results_summary: Citrulline did not significantly alter oxygen cost in young or older adults but improved the rate of oxygen uptake rise at exercise onset in men. No effects were observed in women.
population_specificity: 26 adults (15 women, 11 men) aged 20-35 (young) and 64-86 (older).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Citrulline supplementation on protein metabolism, particularly non-oxidative leucine disposal (NOLD) and splanchnic amino acid extraction, in malnourished older patients.
results_summary: Citrulline supplementation did not significantly affect whole-body or liver protein synthesis but increased systemic amino acid availability. In women, it led to increased lean mass and appendicular skeletal muscle mass and decreased fat mass.
population_specificity: Malnourished older patients (80-92 years; 18 women, 6 men) in inpatient rehabilitation units.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether acute supplementation with citrulline malate (CM) enhances upper-body resistance exercise performance in recreationally resistance-trained men.
results_summary: The study found no significant improvement in exercise performance, muscle swelling, or subjective measures (focus, energy, fatigue) with CM supplementation. A minor interaction was observed in repetitions performed during sets 3 and 4, but overall, CM did not enhance performance.
population_specificity: Recreationally resistance-trained men (21.4 ± 1.6 years; 85.0 ± 12.4 kg).
effective_dosage: 8 g of CM, administered once 40 minutes before exercise.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if citrulline malate supplementation improves muscle recovery after a single session of high-intensity resistance exercise in untrained young adult men.
results_summary: The study found no significant improvement in muscle recovery metrics (e.g., maximum repetitions, perceived exertion, CK levels, lactate levels) with citrulline malate supplementation compared to placebo. Muscle soreness and other variables followed similar recovery patterns in both conditions.
population_specificity: Untrained young adult men (24.0 ± 3.3 years)
study_duration: Single session with follow-up assessments at 24, 48, and 72 hours

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of citrulline malate (CM) on muscular fatigue in healthy, recreationally trained participants.
results_summary: The study found no significant treatment effects of CM on peak torque, peak power, rate of fatigue, or blood lactate accumulation. CM did not improve performance or alleviate fatigue after high-intensity exercise.
population_specificity: Healthy, recreationally trained participants (6 men and 6 women, aged 24.1 ± 3.9 years).
study_duration: Single-dose intervention on separate testing days, each separated by 1 week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of ALA-GLN dipeptide supplementation on plasma amino acid concentrations, including citrulline, in trauma patients.
results_summary: ALA-GLN dipeptide supplementation significantly increased plasma citrulline levels (p = 0.006), indicating a measurable effect, though the clinical relevance of this increase is not detailed.
population_specificity: Trauma patients (n=98)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of citrulline in supporting nitric oxide synthesis and its potential therapeutic effects in MELAS syndrome.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that citrulline, by recycling into arginine, supports nitric oxide synthesis, which may address impaired blood perfusion in MELAS syndrome. However, specific outcomes or clinical results are not detailed.
population_specificity: Patients with MELAS syndrome, a mitochondrial disorder.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of Citrulline/Malate supplementation on blood lactate levels in active handball players undergoing intensive training.
results_summary: The study found a significant 49.8% decrease in blood lactate levels in the Citrulline/Malate group compared to no change in the placebo group, with a 60.7% reduction post-exercise, suggesting it may enhance performance and delay fatigue.
population_specificity: Active handball players
effective_dosage: 1 g three times daily (breakfast, lunch, dinner)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether short-term l-citrulline supplementation increases l-arginine levels, thereby improving exercise blood flow and peripheral dilatation responses in older adults.
results_summary: l-Citrulline increased femoral blood flow by 11% and vascular conductance by 14% during lower-limb exercise in older men, but no changes were observed in older women. This suggests a modest improvement in muscle blood flow for older men, potentially enhancing exercise tolerance.
population_specificity: 25 older adults (13 women and 12 men)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate current management strategies for CPS1 deficiency, including citrulline supplementation, and explore potential novel therapies.
results_summary: The study found that current management with citrulline (and/or arginine) and ammonia scavengers is often insufficient for achieving metabolic stability in CPS1D patients, highlighting the need for alternative treatments.
population_specificity: Patients with carbamoyl phosphate synthetase 1 deficiency (CPS1D), a rare urea cycle disorder.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore potential new therapies, including citrulline, to enhance NO synthase function in treating persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn (PPHN).
results_summary: The abstract suggests citrulline may enhance NO synthase function, but no specific results or data on its efficacy in PPHN are provided. Continued investigation is noted as necessary to determine its therapeutic potential.
population_specificity: Newborn infants (term and preterm) with persistent pulmonary hypertension (PPHN).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the vascular benefits of L-citrulline and watermelon supplementation, focusing on their effects on nitric oxide synthesis, blood pressure, and exercise performance.
results_summary: Acute L-citrulline ingestion increases plasma L-arginine but inconsistently improves nitric oxide production and vasodilation, while chronic supplementation enhances nitric oxide synthesis, reduces blood pressure in hypertensive individuals, and improves exercise performance.
population_specificity: Adults with prehypertension or hypertension, and young healthy adults.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining l-citrulline and l-arginine supplementation more effectively increases plasma l-arginine levels compared to either supplement alone.
results_summary: The study found that combining 1 g of l-citrulline and 1 g of l-arginine increased plasma l-arginine levels more effectively than 2 g of either supplement alone. This suggests a synergistic effect when the two are administered together.
population_specificity: Healthy males
effective_dosage: 1 g l-citrulline + 1 g l-arginine (combined), 2 g l-citrulline (alone), 2 g l-arginine (alone)

study_goal: To examine the effects of acute Citrulline-malate supplementation on grip strength, vertical power, and anaerobic cycling performance in female masters athletes.
results_summary: CM supplementation improved maximal and average grip strength, as well as peak and explosive power during anaerobic cycling, but did not affect vertical power. No significant differences were observed in the ability to sustain power between CM and placebo.
population_specificity: Female masters athletes (51 ± 9 years)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if glutamine supplementation could compensate for reduced citrulline and arginine production caused by ischemia-reperfusion injury during aortic surgery.
results_summary: The study found that intravenous glutamine supplementation significantly increased the production of citrulline and arginine, compensating for the reduced synthesis caused by aortic clamping. The whole-body plasma flux and synthesis rates of these amino acids were higher in the supplemented group compared to the control.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing open abdominal aortic surgery with aortic clamping.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the acute effects of nitrate and citrulline supplementation on post-ischemic vascular response in healthy subjects.
results_summary: The study compared the effects of a drink containing nitrate and citrulline (N+C) versus a placebo on vascular response, measuring changes in total hemoglobin (Hbtot) and oxyhemoglobin (HbO). Results suggested potential benefits of the combined supplementation, but specific outcomes were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Healthy subjects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether l-Citrulline supplementation (l-CIT) could attenuate aortic hemodynamic and arterial stiffness responses to combined metaboreflex activation and cold exposure in healthy, overweight/obese males.
results_summary: l-CIT attenuated increases in aortic blood pressure, wave reflection, and arterial stiffness during exercise-related stress and combined metaboreflex activation with cold exposure, but had no significant effects at rest. Heart rate and reflection timing were unaffected by l-CIT.
population_specificity: Sixteen healthy, overweight/obese males (age 24 ± 6 years; BMI 29.3 ± 4.0 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate citrulline's role as a noninvasive marker of intestinal atrophy in aging rats and its metabolic relationship with glutamine.
results_summary: The study found that enterocytes from very old rats metabolize glutamine into citrulline, enabling citrulline to serve as a marker for age-induced intestinal atrophy. Oral glutamine supplementation in rats improved gut mass and mucosal villus height, preventing gut atrophy.
population_specificity: Very old rats (advanced age).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether oral L-citrulline supplementation improves cycling time trial performance in trained males.
results_summary: L-Citrulline supplementation significantly increased plasma L-arginine levels, reduced 4-km cycling completion time by 1.5%, and improved subjective feelings of muscle fatigue and concentration post-exercise compared to placebo.
population_specificity: 22 trained males
effective_dosage: 2.4 g/day for 7 days, plus an additional 2.4 g 1 hour before the time trial

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the hypolipidemic effect of watermelon extract (containing citrulline) and assess the influence of the MTHFR C677T genotype on supplementation response in individuals with dyslipidemia.
results_summary: Watermelon extract reduced plasma total cholesterol and low-density lipoprotein (LDL) levels without affecting triglycerides, high-density lipoprotein (HDL), or very low-density lipoprotein (VLDL). Only carriers of the T allele (MTHFR C677T) showed significant reductions in LDL levels.
population_specificity: 43 subjects with dyslipidemia, divided into experimental (n=22) and control (n=21) groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the independent and combined effects of l-citrulline supplementation and whole-body vibration training on aortic hemodynamics and plasma nitric oxide metabolites in obese postmenopausal women.
results_summary: All groups showed decreased blood pressures and increased nitric oxide levels, but only the groups involving whole-body vibration training (with or without l-citrulline) reduced wave reflection indices (AIx and AIx@75). The combined intervention (WBVT+l-citrulline) showed significant improvement in AIx@75 compared to l-citrulline alone.
population_specificity: Obese postmenopausal women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of acute citrulline-malate supplementation on acid-base balance and high-intensity exercise performance in well-trained males.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in performance-related variables, acid-base balance, or perceived exertion between the citrulline-malate and placebo groups, despite increased plasma concentrations of citrulline, ornithine, and glutamine. No gastrointestinal side effects were reported.
population_specificity: 10 well-trained males
effective_dosage: 12 g of citrulline-malate in 400 ml, consumed 60 minutes before exercise

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze glutamine's contribution to citrulline synthesis and assess whether glutamine supplementation increases citrulline production.
results_summary: The study found that glutamine may enhance citrulline synthesis indirectly by improving gut function, but there is no strong evidence that glutamine is a major precursor for citrulline in humans. A recent trial showed increased mortality with glutamine supplementation in critically ill patients.
population_specificity: Critically ill patients (mentioned in the context of glutamine supplementation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of acute Citrulline malate (CM) supplementation on upper- and lower-body weightlifting performance in resistance-trained females.
results_summary: Acute CM supplementation significantly increased repetitions completed in both upper- and lower-body exercises and reduced perceived exertion during upper-body exercise, with no significant effects on heart rate.
population_specificity: Resistance-trained females (15 participants, aged 23 ± 3 years).
effective_dosage: 8 g CM + 8 g dextrose, consumed once before exercise.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze creatine kinetics and the effects of creatine and amino acid supplementation, including changes in plasma citrulline levels, in healthy young adults.
results_summary: The study found a significant increase in plasma citrulline levels following creatine supplementation, alongside changes in other amino acids. Citrulline's increase was part of broader metabolic shifts, but its specific functional impact was not detailed.
population_specificity: Healthy young men and women (8 males, 7 females), aged 20-30 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Citrulline and an isonitrogenous mixture of nonessential amino acids on fructose-induced nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) in rats.
results_summary: Citrulline effectively prevented fructose-induced NAFLD, correcting metabolic disturbances, improving Arg bioavailability, and normalizing gene expression related to lipid metabolism. Both Citrulline and NEAAs restored liver function, but Citrulline uniquely restored Fas gene expression and Arg bioavailability to control levels.
population_specificity: Male Sprague Dawley rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of l-citrulline and l-arginine supplementation on nitric oxide biomarkers, pulmonary oxygen uptake kinetics, and exercise performance.
results_summary: Citrulline supplementation increased plasma citrulline concentration, lowered mean arterial blood pressure, improved oxygen uptake kinetics during severe-intensity exercise, and enhanced exercise performance, while arginine supplementation showed limited effects.
population_specificity: 10 healthy adult men

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of L-citrulline and/or GSH on markers of nitric oxide synthesis in vitro, in rodents, and in humans.
results_summary: Combining L-citrulline with GSH significantly increased nitrite and NOx levels in vitro and in vivo, with notable post-exercise increases in humans. Plasma cGMP showed a non-significant increase.
population_specificity: Human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVECs), Sprague-Dawley rats, and resistance-trained males.
effective_dosage: Humans: 2 g/day L-citrulline, 1 g/day GSH, or 2 g/day L-citrulline + 200 mg/day GSH; Rats: 500 mg/kg/day L-citrulline, 50 mg/kg/day GSH.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Citrulline-malate (CM) supplementation improves performance during repeated bouts of resistance exercise in trained individuals.
results_summary: CM ingestion significantly increased repetitions performed in chin-ups, reverse chin-ups, and push-ups compared to placebo, with no significant differences in blood lactate or systolic blood pressure, but a treatment difference in diastolic blood pressure.
population_specificity: Fourteen resistance-trained, college-age males.
study_duration: Single-dose intervention with a one-week washout period between treatments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of citrulline malate, among other metabolic agents, on clinical outcomes related to sarcopenia in older adults.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that citrulline malate, alongside other interventions like resistance training and nutritional supplementation, may improve skeletal muscle protein balance in older adults with sarcopenia, though specific results for citrulline are not detailed.
population_specificity: Older adults with or at risk of sarcopenia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the independent and combined effects of L-citrulline supplementation and whole-body vibration training on arterial stiffness and muscle function in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The combination of L-citrulline and whole-body vibration training reduced aortic stiffness and increased leg lean mass index more effectively than either intervention alone. L-citrulline alone did not significantly improve leg strength or body fat percentage compared to vibration training.
population_specificity: Obese postmenopausal women (aged 58 ± 3 years, BMI 34 ± 2 kg/m²) with prehypertension or hypertension.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a single pre-exercise dose of l-citrulline or watermelon juice on exercise performance metrics compared to a placebo.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between l-citrulline, watermelon juice, and placebo in improving exercise performance metrics such as repetitions, time to exhaustion, VO2max, anaerobic threshold, or flow-mediated vasodilation. There were also no effects based on gender or supplement timing.
population_specificity: 22 participants (11 males)
effective_dosage: 6 g l-citrulline or ~1.0 g citrulline from 710 mL watermelon juice, administered once before exercise

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether low plasma arginine levels in critically ill patients are linked to granulocytic myeloid-derived suppressor cells (gMDSC) and whether targeting these cells, rather than supplementing with L-arginine, could improve immunosuppression.
results_summary: The study found that critically ill patients had elevated gMDSC levels, which inversely correlated with arginine levels. High gMDSC levels were associated with increased mortality at day 7, but L-arginine supplementation did not show clinical benefit.
population_specificity: Non-surgical critically ill patients (n=28) admitted to a medical intensive care unit (MICU).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether citrulline malate supplementation improves exercise performance, blood lactate, heart rate, and blood pressure during lower-body resistance exercise in trained men.
results_summary: Citrulline malate significantly increased the number of repetitions performed during lower-body resistance exercises compared to placebo, but did not significantly affect blood lactate, heart rate, or blood pressure.
population_specificity: Advanced resistance-trained male subjects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential therapeutic utility of citrulline in MELAS syndrome by assessing its role as a nitric oxide precursor and its comparative efficacy to arginine.
results_summary: The study suggests that citrulline may raise nitric oxide production more effectively than arginine, potentially offering better therapeutic effects for MELAS syndrome, but controlled studies are needed to confirm these effects on clinical outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with MELAS syndrome, a maternally inherited mitochondrial disorder.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of a protein-energy-enriched formula (PE-formula) compared to a standard infant formula (S-formula) on arginine kinetics and nitric oxide synthesis in critically ill infants.
results_summary: The PE-formula increased arginine appearance and nitric oxide synthesis but did not affect citrulline production or plasma arginine concentrations.
population_specificity: Critically ill infants (aged 0.23 ± 0.14 years) with respiratory failure due to viral bronchiolitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of L-citrulline-rich watermelon supplementation on aortic hemodynamic responses to cold pressor test in hypertensive adults.
results_summary: Watermelon supplementation reduced brachial and aortic systolic blood pressure, wave reflection magnitude, and myocardial oxygen demand during cold exposure, but did not affect baseline augmentation pressure or index. It attenuated cold-induced increases in wave reflection.
population_specificity: Obese adults with hypertension (13 individuals, 10 women, average age 57±1 years, baseline brachial systolic BP 151±5 mm Hg).
effective_dosage: Not specified (watermelon supplementation used, exact L-citrulline dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the evidence on the effect of citrulline malate on sarcopenia and muscular outcomes in older adults, including its biological plausibility.
results_summary: The study reviewed existing evidence suggesting that citrulline malate may have a positive impact on muscle outcomes in older adults, though the results were not strongly conclusive. The biological plausibility of its effects was discussed, but specific efficacy data were limited.
population_specificity: Older adults with or at risk of sarcopenia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between intestinal mucosal function (measured by plasma citrulline concentration) and zinc absorption in children.
results_summary: The study found that baseline plasma citrulline concentration was not associated with changes in plasma zinc concentration, suggesting citrulline did not influence zinc absorption efficacy. Zinc supplementation significantly increased plasma zinc levels regardless of intestinal permeability.
population_specificity: 282 apparently healthy children aged 6 to 23 months in Burkina Faso.
effective_dosage: Not specified for citrulline (study focused on 5 mg zinc sulfate daily).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of nitric oxide (NO) in metabolic regulation and the potential of L-arginine or L-citrulline supplementation to prevent and treat metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: The study found that physiological levels of NO regulate energy metabolism by stimulating glucose and fatty acid uptake while inhibiting glucose, glycogen, and fat synthesis. Chronic NO exposure promotes angiogenesis, blood flow, mitochondrial biogenesis, and brown adipocyte development, suggesting L-arginine or L-citrulline supplementation could mitigate metabolic syndrome.
population_specificity: Mammals, including humans (no specific subpopulation detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether L-citrulline-rich watermelon supplementation reduces arterial stiffness, wave reflection characteristics, and aortic systolic blood pressure in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: Watermelon supplementation significantly reduced arterial stiffness (baPWV), aortic systolic blood pressure, and diastolic blood pressure, as well as radial and aortic SBP2, indicating improved vascular function. The reductions in aortic SBP were strongly correlated with decreases in radial and aortic SBP2.
population_specificity: Obese postmenopausal women with hypertension (mean age 57, mean BMI 38.1 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether low citrulline levels in severe sepsis patients are associated with ARDS and if citrulline supplementation could prevent ARDS development.
results_summary: Plasma citrulline levels were significantly lower in ARDS patients compared to non-ARDS patients, with the lowest quartile showing a 50% ARDS rate versus 15% in the highest quartile. Low citrulline levels were independently associated with ARDS, suggesting a potential role in NOS uncoupling and oxidative injury.
population_specificity: 135 patients with severe sepsis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of egg white protein versus carbohydrate intake on fat-free mass, muscle strength, and blood biochemistry, including serum citrulline levels, in female athletes.
results_summary: The study found that serum citrulline levels increased significantly in the protein group after 8 weeks, but there were no significant differences in body composition or muscle strength between the protein and carbohydrate groups.
population_specificity: Thirty healthy female collegiate athletes matched by sport type, body fat percentage, and muscle strength.
effective_dosage: 15.0 g egg white protein daily (containing citrulline as a metabolite).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of L-citrulline supplementation on functional class, ejection fraction, and peripheral blood flow in patients with systolic heart failure.
results_summary: L-citrulline supplementation significantly improved left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF), endothelial function (MAT/TT index), and functional class in patients with systolic heart failure, with statistically significant changes compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Stable outpatients with systolic heart failure attending the Heart Failure Clinic at the INCMNSZ.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the therapeutic potential of L-Citrulline, its role as a biomarker, and its efficacy in various conditions including intestinal pathology, erectile dysfunction, and rheumatoid arthritis.
results_summary: L-Citrulline is effective as a hydroxyl radical scavenger and a precursor for arginine and nitric oxide, with potential therapeutic applications in multiple conditions. It also serves as a biomarker for intestinal pathology and early rheumatoid arthritis detection via Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibodies.
population_specificity: Patients with conditions like short bowel syndrome, erectile dysfunction, sickle cell anemia, hyperlipidemia, cancer chemotherapy, hypercholestremia, hyperoxic lung damage, urea cycle disorders, Alzheimer's disease, multi-infarct dementia, and rheumatoid arthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of citrulline cycling in regulating endothelial nitric oxide synthase (eNOS) activity and its implications for cardiovascular health, particularly in diabetes.
results_summary: The study highlighted the importance of the global arginine bioavailability ratio, which includes citrulline cycling, in influencing eNOS activity. It suggested that modulating factors like tetrahydrobiopterin levels and redox regulation could improve nitric oxide bioavailability.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on cardiovascular complications, particularly in diabetes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of L-arginine supplementation on plasma levels of ADMA, L-citrulline, L-arginine, and total antioxidant status in patients with mild arterial hypertension.
results_summary: L-arginine supplementation significantly increased plasma levels of arginine, citrulline, and total antioxidant status in hypertensive patients. However, it also increased ADMA concentrations, indicating a complex interaction between arginine and ADMA metabolism.
population_specificity: 54 participants (24 women, 30 men) with mild arterial hypertension and healthy controls.
effective_dosage: 2 g tid or 4 g tid of L-arginine.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of L-citrulline malate supplementation on nitric oxide metabolism and its potential ergogenic benefits in athletic performance.
results_summary: The study found that L-citrulline malate may increase nitric oxide metabolites and improve recovery by aiding ammonia elimination and serving as a precursor for L-arginine and creatine, but it did not enhance exercise performance in trained athletes. Untrained or moderately healthy subjects showed improved exercise tolerance, while highly-trained subjects saw no performance benefits.
population_specificity: Untrained, moderately healthy, and highly-trained subjects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the potential side effects of chronic glutamine (GLN) supplementation, including its impact on citrulline levels and related metabolic pathways.
results_summary: The study found that chronic GLN supplementation may lead to increased plasma levels of citrulline, along with other amino acids, and could negatively affect amino acid transport, metabolism, and immune function.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of GLN supplementation effects).
effective_dosage: Not specified for citrulline (GLN dosage mentioned as ~40 g/d).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential therapeutic effects of citrulline supplementation on nitric oxide deficiency-related manifestations in mitochondrial diseases.
results_summary: Citrulline was found to be a more efficient nitric oxide donor than arginine, potentially improving symptoms in mitochondrial diseases, but clinical evidence is limited to uncontrolled studies showing benefits in MELAS syndrome.
population_specificity: Subjects with mitochondrial diseases, specifically MELAS syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test whether soy isoflavone supplementation affected nitric oxide metabolism (assessed via citrulline flux) and blood pressure in menopausal women with high normal blood pressure.
results_summary: The study found no effect of soy isoflavone supplementation on citrulline flux, nitric oxide synthesis, blood pressure, or vascular hemodynamics compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Menopausal women with high normal blood pressure (n=24, 12 per group).
effective_dosage: 80 mg soy hypocotyl isoflavones (in aglycone units) daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of citrulline as a precursor for arginine production and its potential therapeutic applications in conditions characterized by impaired NO metabolism and NOS3 uncoupling.
results_summary: The study highlights citrulline's importance in de novo arginine production and its potential to improve NO bioavailability, particularly in cardiovascular and pulmonary disorders. It suggests therapeutic strategies involving citrulline supplementation to address arginine deficiency and NOS3 uncoupling.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of conditions like atherosclerosis, diabetes, hypertension, etc.)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of watermelon extract (containing L-citrulline and L-arginine) on ankle blood pressure and carotid wave reflection in individuals with prehypertension or stage 1 hypertension and normal ankle-brachial index.
results_summary: Watermelon extract supplementation significantly reduced ankle and brachial blood pressure (systolic, diastolic, and mean arterial pressure) and carotid wave reflection (cAIx) compared to placebo, suggesting improved arterial function. No significant effects were observed on ankle-brachial index or heart rate.
population_specificity: Obese middle-aged adults (11 women, 3 men, mean age 58 ± 1 years) with prehypertension or stage 1 hypertension and normal ankle-brachial index.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of l-citrulline supplementation in managing lysinuric protein intolerance (LPI) and its potential complications, particularly focusing on immune dysfunction and arginine accumulation.
results_summary: The study found that while l-citrulline supplementation is part of standard LPI treatment, excessive dosage may worsen intracellular arginine accumulation, potentially contributing to immune dysfunction and severe multisystem complications. The abstract suggests reconsidering l-citrulline dosage to mitigate adverse effects.
population_specificity: Patients with lysinuric protein intolerance (LPI), an inherited disorder affecting cationic amino acid transport.
effective_dosage: Not specified (mentions "lowering the l-citrulline dosage" but no exact amount or frequency provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of Citrulline as a secondary NO donor in the NOS-dependent pathway and its potential effects on exercise performance.
results_summary: The study found mixed results regarding Citrulline's efficacy in improving exercise performance, with benefits observed in untrained or moderately trained subjects but no significant effects in highly trained individuals. The role of Citrulline in NO production and its potential ergogenic effects were highlighted, though further research is needed.
population_specificity: Healthy, trained and untrained young male subjects (elderly and female populations noted as needing further research).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess nitric oxide (NO) production in MELAS syndrome subjects and evaluate the effects of arginine and citrulline supplementation on NO metabolism.
results_summary: Subjects with MELAS had impaired NO production due to reduced citrulline availability, elevated ADMA, and higher arginine clearance. Citrulline supplementation significantly improved de novo arginine synthesis, plasma arginine and citrulline levels, and NO production, outperforming arginine.
population_specificity: Subjects with mitochondrial encephalomyopathy, lactic acidosis, and stroke-like episodes (MELAS) syndrome and control subjects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review recent findings on the effects of arginine deficiency in disease and assess the potential of arginine or citrulline supplementation to address these deficiencies.
results_summary: The study found that arginine deficiency, often due to elevated plasma arginase, can impair T-cell function and macrophage cytokine production. There is limited information on the safety and efficacy of citrulline supplementation in specific diseases, indicating a need for further research.
population_specificity: Not specified (broad review of diseases with arginine deficiency)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the role of citrulline in diagnosing and managing argininosuccinate lyase deficiency (ASLD), a urea cycle disorder.
results_summary: The study found that elevated plasma citrulline, along with argininosuccinic acid, is a key diagnostic marker for ASLD. Treatment involves dietary protein restriction and arginine supplementation, but citrulline's direct therapeutic role was not highlighted.
population_specificity: Patients with argininosuccinate lyase deficiency (ASLD), including neonatal-onset and late-onset forms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether citrulline supplementation affects protein metabolism in healthy volunteers.
results_summary: Citrulline increased plasma citrulline, arginine, and ornithine concentrations but did not affect whole-body protein kinetics, nitrogen balance, or other measured metabolic markers.
population_specificity: 12 healthy adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of low-dose citrulline supplementation in managing lysinuric protein intolerance (LPI) as part of a broader therapeutic approach.
results_summary: Citrulline supplementation, alongside a low protein diet and other supplements, was used to manage LPI symptoms, including hyperammonemia, but no specific efficacy data on citrulline alone were provided. The study noted variability in clinical presentation and the need for individualized therapy.
population_specificity: Patients with lysinuric protein intolerance (LPI), a rare inherited metabolic disorder.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore whether dietary supplementation with L-citrulline could be beneficial for managing overweight or obese gestating women by reducing white-fat accretion.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that L-citrulline may be beneficial for managing overweight or obese gestating women by reducing white-fat accretion, but it primarily emphasizes the need for animal models to test these hypotheses due to ethical concerns in human studies.
population_specificity: Overweight or obese gestating women (though the study primarily discusses animal models for future research).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the efficacy and safety of oral L-citrulline supplementation in improving erection hardness in patients with mild erectile dysfunction (ED).
results_summary: L-citrulline supplementation significantly improved erection hardness scores in 50% of participants compared to 8.3% with placebo, increased the mean number of intercourses per month, and was well-tolerated with no adverse events reported.
population_specificity: Men with mild ED (erection hardness score of 3), mean age 56.5 ± 9.8 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the short-term effects of L-citrulline supplementation on arterial stiffness in humans.
results_summary: L-citrulline significantly reduced arterial stiffness (measured by baPWV) and increased serum NOx levels and plasma arginine, without affecting blood pressure. The improvements correlated with increased plasma arginine levels.
population_specificity: 15 healthy male subjects aged 58.3 ± 4.4 years with elevated arterial stiffness (baPWV >1400 cm/sec).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of uncoupled eNOS in cardiovascular and pulmonary disorders and explore therapeutic approaches, including Citrulline supplementation, to modulate eNOS activity.
results_summary: The study highlights that Citrulline, as a substrate for eNOS, contributes to nitric oxide production, which has vasodilatory and anti-atherosclerotic effects. However, eNOS uncoupling can lead to harmful reactive oxygen species generation, suggesting the need for targeted therapeutic modulation.
population_specificity: Broad cardiovascular and pulmonary disorder contexts, including atherosclerosis, ventricular remodeling, and pulmonary hypertension.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of L-citrulline on blood pressure and right ventricular function in patients with heart failure and preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF).
results_summary: The study found that citrulline malate (3 g/day) significantly decreased pulmonary artery pressure and improved right ventricular ejection fraction post-exercise, along with reductions in diastolic and systolic blood pressure. No statistically significant differences were observed between the citrulline and L-arginine groups.
population_specificity: Chronic, stable patients with heart failure and preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Citrulline (CIT) is more effective than arginine (ARG) in improving protein synthesis and arginine availability, particularly in conditions of intestinal failure or low protein intake.
results_summary: CIT supplementation improved protein synthesis and arginine availability more effectively than ARG, likely due to its efficient transport into enterocytes and avoidance of hepatic uptake. CIT's action on protein synthesis is mediated through the mTOR pathway, and it may serve as a safe way to deliver ARG to endothelial and immune cells while preventing excessive nitric oxide production.
population_specificity: Rats with short bowel syndrome, malnourished rats, and healthy volunteers fed a hypoproteic diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of oral arginine supplementation on exhaled nitric oxide levels (FE(NO)) in sickle cell disease patients with and without a history of acute chest syndrome, as well as in healthy controls.
results_summary: After arginine supplementation, FE(NO), arginine, ornithine, citrulline, nitrite, and the arginine/ornithine ratio increased similarly in all groups, with minimal changes in lung function and physiological parameters. The study found no significant differences in FE(NO) increase between sickle cell patients and healthy controls.
population_specificity: Sickle cell disease patients with (n=6) and without (n=9) a history of acute chest syndrome, and healthy controls (n=7).
effective_dosage: Escalating doses of oral L-arginine (0.1, 0.2, and 0.4 g/kg).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of citrulline supplementation in maintaining arginine pools and nitrogen homeostasis after intestinal resection.
results_summary: Citrulline was found to be more effective than arginine at sustaining arginine pools and maintaining nitrogen homeostasis when administered at 1 g/kg/day, whether given enterally or parenterally. The study suggests citrulline supplementation may be beneficial for short bowel patients.
population_specificity: Patients with significant intestinal resection (short bowel syndrome).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a single dose of citrulline malate (CM) on anaerobic exercise performance (flat barbell bench presses) and post-exercise muscle soreness reduction.
results_summary: CM significantly increased repetitions to fatigue by 52.92% in later sets and reduced muscle soreness by 40% at 24 and 48 hours post-exercise, with over 90% response rate. The only reported side effect was stomach discomfort in 14.63% of subjects.
population_specificity: 41 men performing pectoral training sessions.
effective_dosage: 8 grams of CM in a single dose.
study_duration: Single-dose intervention across two training sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of citrulline in addressing arginine deficiency and its potential to enhance nitric oxide production in conditions like hypertension and sepsis.
results_summary: The study found that citrulline supplementation could improve nitric oxide production in cases of arginine deficiency, suggesting its therapeutic potential for conditions like hypertension and sepsis. However, the abstract does not provide specific efficacy data or clinical outcomes.
population_specificity: Septic patients and transgenic mice models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether oral L-citrulline supplementation reduces brachial and aortic blood pressure responses to the cold pressor test in young normotensive men.
results_summary: Oral L-citrulline significantly decreased brachial systolic blood pressure, aortic systolic blood pressure, and aortic pulse pressure during the cold pressor test but not at rest. Increased wave reflection time contributed to the reduction in aortic systolic blood pressure response.
population_specificity: 17 young normotensive men (average age 21.6 ± 0.9 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of aromatherapy using Jasminum and Salvia officinalis (Clary sage) on sexual dysfunction in women of reproductive age.
results_summary: The study found that both Jasminum and Salvia officinalis improved sexual dysfunction, with Salvia officinalis showing superior effects in mental arousal, lubrication, and sexual pain compared to Jasminum. The results were statistically significant.
population_specificity: Women aged 15-45 with sexual dysfunction (FSFI score < 28).
effective_dosage: Twice daily for 6 weeks (specific amount not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether inhaling clary sage (CS) or linalyl acetate (LA) could alleviate depression, anxiety, and stress in diabetic foot ulcer (DFU) patients with varying degrees of depression.
results_summary: Inhalation of CS oil significantly reduced stress in DFU patients with mild depression, while LA significantly reduced anxiety and depression in those with moderate to severe depression compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 72 patients with diabetic foot ulcers, categorized as having mild (43) or moderate to severe (29) depression.
effective_dosage: 5% CS oil or 5% LA via natural breathing.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the interactive effects of zinc (Zn) and cadmium (Cd) on clary sage and determine whether excess Zn could mitigate Cd toxicity in the plant.
results_summary: The study found that co-exposure to Zn and Cd increased leaf content of essential elements (Fe, Mg, Ca, Mn, Cu) and antioxidant capacity, suggesting Zn's protective role against Cd toxicity. Leaf morphology showed fewer alterations under combined treatment compared to Cd-only exposure.
population_specificity: Hydroponically grown clary sage plants

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the soil fungal and arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi (AMF) community composition in TE-polluted soils under clary sage cultivation and the effects of AMF inoculation.
results_summary: The study found that clary sage cultivation and AMF inoculation significantly shaped fungal communities in TE-polluted soils, increasing AMF diversity in roots. Successive years of cultivation also influenced fungal and AMF community variation.
population_specificity: Clary sage (Salvia sclarea L.) grown in TE-polluted agricultural soil near a former lead smelter.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of watermelon supplementation (containing L-citrulline and L-arginine) on aortic blood pressure and arterial function in individuals with prehypertension.
results_summary: Watermelon supplementation significantly improved aortic hemodynamics, reducing brachial pulse pressure, aortic systolic blood pressure, aortic pulse pressure, and augmentation index, but had no significant effect on other measured parameters like brachial systolic blood pressure or carotid-femoral pulse wave velocity.
population_specificity: Nine subjects (four men, five women, age 54 ± 3 years) with prehypertension (134/77 ± 5/3 mm Hg).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility of using clary sage essential oil inhalation to influence oxytocin levels in pregnant women near term.
results_summary: The study found mixed results on oxytocin levels post-inhalation, with some increases in both the experiment and control groups, but no observed uterine contractions. Cortisol levels decreased in both groups, and the protocol was deemed practical and acceptable with no negative effects.
population_specificity: Pregnant women with singleton pregnancies between 38 and 40 gestation weeks (N=11).
effective_dosage: 50-fold dilution of clary sage essential oil with 10 mL of odorless propylene glycol, inhaled for 20 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of clary sage oil and its main components (linalool and linalyl acetate) on the plasma membrane fluidity and apoptosis in Candida albicans cells.
results_summary: The study found that clary sage oil and its components increased plasma membrane fluidity, with linalyl acetate showing the strongest effect. These changes led to metabolite loss and apoptosis in Candida albicans cells.
population_specificity: Candida albicans (human pathogenic yeast) cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antibacterial potential of clove essential oil, acetylated essential oil, eugenol, and acetyleugenol against Staphylococcus aureus, Escherichia coli, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
results_summary: All tested compounds showed strong antibacterial activity, with eugenol being particularly effective against S. aureus and P. aeruginosa, exhibiting inhibition diameters of 25 mm and MIC values of 0.58 mg/mL and 2.32 mg/mL, respectively.
population_specificity: Bacterial strains (S. aureus, E. coli, P. aeruginosa) in vitro.
effective_dosage: MIC values: 0.58 mg/mL (S. aureus), 2.32 mg/mL (P. aeruginosa); MIB values: 2.32 mg/mL (S. aureus), 9.28 mg/mL (P. aeruginosa).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of different doses of clove hydroalcoholic extracts on liver function in rats with thioacetamide-induced hepatotoxicity.
results_summary: Clove extract significantly improved liver damage by reducing serum liver enzyme levels and increasing total plasma protein and albumin in rats with thioacetamide-induced hepatotoxicity. The effects were dose-dependent, with all tested doses (50, 150, and 300 mg/kg) showing benefits.
population_specificity: Rats with thioacetamide-induced hepatotoxicity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of clove bud powder (CBP) dietary administration on broiler chickens' performance and jejunum morphology.
results_summary: CBP negatively affected broiler performance (reduced body weight, daily weight gain, feed consumption, and increased feed conversion ratio) but improved intestinal morphology (increased villus height and villus height/crypt depth ratio).
population_specificity: 1-day-old broiler chicks (Ross 308)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate a clove oil-based nanoscale emulgel (LFX-NE gel) for treating Pseudomonas aeruginosa biofilm-infected burn wounds in mice.
results_summary: The LFX-NE gel demonstrated complete drug release in 8 hours, dispersed biofilms, promoted wound healing, and cleared infections within 7 days, outperforming control groups.
population_specificity: Mice with Pseudomonas aeruginosa biofilm-infected burn wounds.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a combination of clove, Sophora flower bud, and Chinese yam (DACHAO) could improve ovarian function and fertility in aged female mice.
results_summary: DACHAO improved mitochondrial function in oocytes, increased blastocyst formation, reduced apoptosis, and enhanced fertility in aged mice, likely through antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and hormonal mechanisms.
population_specificity: Aged female mice (10 months old).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the antifungal effect of clove essential oil (CEO) and eugenol (EUG) against Candida spp. strains, their mode of action, and interactions with selected antimycotics.
results_summary: CEO and EUG showed antifungal activity against all tested Candida strains (MIC 0.25-2 mg/mL), binding to ergosterol in yeast cell membranes. Synergistic or additive effects were observed when combined with certain antimycotics, except nystatin.
population_specificity: Clinical Candida spp. strains isolated from the oral cavity of patients with hematological malignancies.
effective_dosage: Minimal inhibitory concentration (MIC) range of 0.25-2 mg/mL.
interactions: Synergistic/additive effects with cetylpyridinium chloride, chlorhexidine, silver nitrate, and triclosan; no synergy with nystatin.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the wound-healing potential of clove oil nanoemulsions stabilized with chitosan oleate, particularly for chronic or diabetic wounds and burns.
results_summary: The study found that clove oil nanoemulsions demonstrated strong antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties, promoted wound closure in a murine burn model, and maintained stability over several months. Histological analysis confirmed improved lesion repair after 18 days.
population_specificity: Murine (mouse) burn model

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of clove essential oil (specifically eugenol) and other phenolic substances in controlling black rot disease caused by Xanthomonas campestris pv. campestris (Xcc) in cabbage seeds and plants.
results_summary: Clove-derived eugenol, particularly in combination with thymol, showed strong antibacterial effects against Xcc, achieving complete elimination of the bacterium from cabbage seeds at specific concentrations. The treatment also successfully eliminated bacterial infection in germinated cabbage plants, as confirmed by plate counting and qPCR methods.
population_specificity: Cabbage seeds and germinated cabbage plants infested with Xanthomonas campestris pv. campestris (Xcc).
effective_dosage: 0.0195% eugenol (from clove essential oil); synergistic effect observed with 0.0049% carvacrol and 0.0195% thymol.
study_duration: 30 minutes for in vitro tests; duration for plant treatments not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of clove powder, combined with tulsi extract, on broiler growth performance, gut health, and cecal microbial status as an alternative to antibiotic growth promoters.
results_summary: The study found that a specific dosage (1% clove + 3% tulsi) significantly improved growth parameters, gut morphology, and cecal microbial status, while other dosages showed no significant effects. The combination increased beneficial bacteria (Lactobacillus spp.) and reduced harmful bacteria (E. coli).
population_specificity: Day-old Cobb-500 strain broiler chicks (60 birds divided into 4 groups).
effective_dosage: 0.5% clove + 2% tulsi (T1), 1% clove + 3% tulsi (T2), 1.5% clove + 4% tulsi (T3), administered via drinking water.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to improve the stability and solubility of clove essential oil (CEO) using microencapsulation with β-CD-MOFs and evaluate its preservation effects on Chinese bacon.
results_summary: Microencapsulated CEO showed enhanced antioxidant activities, improved ROS scavenging abilities, and greater thermo-/pH-stability compared to unencapsulated CEO. It also reduced lipid oxidation in Chinese bacon more effectively than CEO alone or synthetic antioxidants (BHT).
population_specificity: Chinese bacon (preserved meat products)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a combination of Capsicum oleoresin and clove essential oil on lactational performance, nutrient utilization, enteric methane emissions, and blood parameters in dairy cows.
results_summary: The study found that clove essential oil supplementation linearly decreased daily methane emissions by up to 7.5%, tended to increase milk fat content, and had variable effects on blood parameters (e.g., reduced serum β-hydroxybutyrate and insulin in primiparous cows). Other measures like dry matter intake and milk production remained unaffected.
population_specificity: Twenty Holstein dairy cows (12 multiparous and 8 primiparous) averaging 77 ± 28 days in milk.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether clove bud oil incorporated into polycaprolactone fibres could serve as an effective antimicrobial wound dressing.
results_summary: The clove bud oil fibres demonstrated good antimicrobial properties, with inhibition zones of 30, 18, 11, and 20 mm against C. albicans, E. coli, S. aureus, and S. pyogenes, respectively. The fibres also exhibited advantageous physical properties, with diameters of 10.90 ± 4.99 μm.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study using microbial colonies).
effective_dosage: 44.4% (v/v) clove bud oil in polycaprolactone fibres.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate clove flower extract (Syzygium aromaticum) as a potential anticancer agent by assessing its toxicity (LC50) and molecular docking interactions.
results_summary: Clove flower extract showed toxicity to Artemia salina larvae with an LC50 of 227.1 g/ml, and molecular docking indicated eugenol acetate's proximity to nitric oxide synthase (3E7G), suggesting potential anticancer effects via enzyme inhibition.
population_specificity: Artemia salina leach larvae (in vitro model).
effective_dosage: 50 ppm, 250 ppm, 500 ppm, 750 ppm, 1000 ppm (single exposure).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the composition, antifungal, and insecticidal properties of essential oils extracted from clove buds (Jambosa caryophyllus).
