results_summary: The study found that clove essential oil exhibited significant antifungal activity (49-87% inhibition) against Aspergillus niger, Aspergillus flavus, and Fusarium oxysporum, with MIC values between 3.125 and 7.80 μg/mL. It also demonstrated insecticidal activity against Callosobruchus maculatus, with LD50 values of 2.32 μL/L air (inhalation) and 5.51 μL/L air (contact) after 96 hours.
population_specificity: Fungi (Aspergillus niger, Aspergillus flavus, Fusarium oxysporum) and insects (Callosobruchus maculatus).
effective_dosage: 4, 8, 16, and 32 μL EO-JC for repulsion tests; MIC values of 3.125-7.80 μg/mL for antifungal activity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of eugenol (EU), a major compound in clove oil, in preventing obesity and to understand the mechanisms involved.
results_summary: EU significantly reduced obesity-related indexes, prevented gut dysbiosis, and induced transcriptomic reprogramming in white adipose tissue in mice fed a high-fat diet. The effects were correlated with specific changes in gut microbiota.
population_specificity: Five-week-old male C57BL/6J mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of clove essential oil (CEO) on oxidative stress, glucose metabolism enzymes, and proinflammatory mediators in diabetic rats.
results_summary: CEO administration significantly reduced blood glucose, total cholesterol, and xanthine oxidase levels, improved antioxidant and metabolic enzyme activities, and lowered lipid peroxides and thiols in liver and brain tissues. It also inhibited α-amylase and reduced iNOS expression in the spleen, suggesting potential benefits for diabetes-related complications.
population_specificity: Streptozotocin-induced diabetic rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of clove essential oil (CEO) in enhancing the properties of polylactic acid (PLA) nanocomposite films for food packaging applications.
results_summary: The study found that PLA nanocomposites with 0.5 wt% NHNT and 200 μL CEO significantly improved physical, thermal, mechanical, and barrier properties, as well as extended the shelf life of cut apples by reducing weight loss, microbial growth, and maintaining fruit quality.
population_specificity: Cut apples stored at room temperature (in vitro food packaging test).
effective_dosage: 200 μL clove essential oil (CEO) per nanocomposite film.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify bioactive compounds in clove that could inhibit SARS-CoV-2 main protease activity, potentially serving as a therapeutic intervention for COVID-19.
results_summary: Four bioactive compounds from clove (eugenie, syzyginin B, eugenol, and casuarictin) showed potential binding properties against SARS-CoV-2 main protease, suggesting inhibition of viral replication. Further validation through molecular dynamics simulation was performed, but in vitro and in vivo studies are needed for conclusive efficacy.
population_specificity: Not specified (in silico study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of combining linseed oil and clove leaf essential oil on fatty acid incorporation, oxidative markers, and gene expression in zebrafish muscle.
results_summary: The study found increased n-3 fatty acid incorporation in muscle, reduced oxidative enzyme activities, increased glutathione content, lower lipid peroxidation with 1% CLEO, and higher PPAR-α and SREBP-2 gene expression with 9% LO + 0.5% CLEO.
population_specificity: Zebrafish
effective_dosage: 0.5% and 1% clove leaf essential oil (CLEO) combined with 3%, 6%, or 9% linseed oil (LO)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of clove oil incorporation and sonication on the physical, antioxidant, antimicrobial, and lipid oxidation-inhibiting properties of mung bean flour-based films.
results_summary: Clove oil and sonication improved the physical strength, antioxidant activity, and antimicrobial properties of the films, with significant inhibition of lipid oxidation indicators. The MFCU films (with clove oil and sonication) showed the highest performance in tensile strength, radical scavenging, and antibacterial control.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on film properties)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the anti-inflammatory and anti-nociceptive effects of Clove essential oil nanogels in an animal model.
results_summary: The study found that Clove nanogels significantly reduced inflammation (paw edema test) and pain (hot plate and formalin test), demonstrating strong anti-nociceptive and anti-inflammatory effects.
population_specificity: Animal model (specific species not mentioned in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of eugenol (EUG), a component of clove, on autophagy and inflammation, both alone and in combination with spermidine (SPD), to assess its potential benefits for COVID-19 risk groups.
results_summary: The study found that EUG (0.2 mM) significantly increased autophagy without cytotoxic effects, upregulated crucial autophagy proteins, and reduced inflammation in vitro, with comparable benefits to SPD and the combination therapy (SPD + EUG).
population_specificity: In vitro cell lines (HBEpiC, SHSY5Y, HUVEC, Caco-2, L929, and U937).
effective_dosage: 0.2 mM EUG, 0.3 mM SPD, and combination (0.3 mM SPD + 0.2 mM EUG).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of clove-based nanoemulsions as a coating for muffins to enhance antioxidant activity, maintain texture, and extend shelf life.
results_summary: Clove oil nanoemulsion coating significantly increased antioxidant activity by 37.31%, maintained muffin texture, reduced weight loss, and extended shelf life up to 6 days without quality deterioration.
population_specificity: Muffin samples (in vitro food application)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antibacterial and wound-healing effects of clove flower extract (CFE) on diabetic foot ulcers (DFU) caused by multidrug-resistant Proteus mirabilis.
results_summary: CFE demonstrated significant antibacterial activity against P. mirabilis and improved wound healing in diabetic rats by modulating inflammatory markers, growth factors, and oxidative stress, comparable to cefepime therapy.
population_specificity: Type 1 diabetic albino rats (Rattus norvegicus) with induced diabetic foot ulcers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the antimicrobial activity and safety of clove essential oil (CEO) incorporated into electrospun nanofibre membranes for wound treatment.
results_summary: The study found that CEO-loaded nanofibre membranes exhibited good inhibitory activity against E. coli and higher activity against S. aureus, with no cytotoxicity observed. The membranes also demonstrated antioxidant activity and released CEO under physiological conditions after 24 hours.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vivo antimicrobial tests, but no human subjects mentioned).
effective_dosage: Not specified (CEO incorporated into electrospun solution, but exact concentration not provided).
study_duration: Not specified (CEO release measured after 24 hours, but total study duration unclear).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether inhalation of a proprietary essential oil blend (including Clove) could improve energy levels in female COVID-19 survivors experiencing long-term fatigue.
results_summary: The study found that inhalation of the essential oil blend significantly reduced fatigue scores, with notable improvements in vigor and various fatigue subscales, demonstrating a large effect size.
population_specificity: Female survivors of COVID-19 experiencing fatigue more than five months post-recovery.
effective_dosage: Inhalation twice daily (specific amount not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of clove type, cold storage duration, and GA3 treatment on garlic clove dormancy, emergence, growth, and yield.
results_summary: The study found that 30 days of cold storage and topping of cloves significantly reduced dormancy and days to maturity while increasing total bulb yield by 70.32% compared to the control. GA3 treatment showed nonsignificant effects on emergence but interacted with other factors to influence growth and yield components.
population_specificity: Garlic cloves of the "Tseday" variety grown during the main cropping season of 2014/2015 and off-season of 2015/16 at Haramaya University.
study_duration: Cold storage durations of 10, 20, and 30 days; GA3 treatment duration not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of clove/cinnamon oils-loaded emulgel in treating Candida albicans-associated denture stomatitis.
results_summary: The optimized clove/cinnamon emulgel significantly reduced Candida colony counts and alleviated inflammation, outperforming a commercially available gel with better clinical cure rates and no side effects.
population_specificity: 42 patients with denture stomatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a lipid nanocarrier for controlled release of clove oil to enhance its therapeutic effects in treating rheumatoid arthritis.
results_summary: The nanostructured lipid carriers loaded with clove oil (CONCs) showed improved antiarthritic activity compared to neat clove oil, inhibiting serum lysosomal enzymes and proinflammatory cytokines while enhancing hind leg function. The CONCs demonstrated efficient delivery and stability, with 84.5% entrapment efficiency.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and in vivo biological tests).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-tumor and apoptotic effects of a nanoemulsion form of clove bud essential oil (SABE-NE) against human HT-29 colon cancer cells and assess its cytoprotective properties in mice.
results_summary: SABE-NE induced apoptosis and cellular death in HT-29 cancer cells while showing minimal cytotoxic effects on normal cells. In vivo tests demonstrated reduced lipid peroxidation and increased antioxidant enzyme expression in mice livers, indicating cytoprotective effects.
population_specificity: Human HT-29 colon cancer cells, normal HFF cell lines, and mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if clove extract could effectively treat coral ciliate infections without harming the coral or its symbiotic organisms.
results_summary: The study found that a 1500 ppm clove extract solution was effective at killing ciliates within 10 minutes without causing significant adverse effects on coral health markers like SOD, CAT, chlorophyll a, and zooxanthellae. Tissue examination confirmed the absence of ciliates post-treatment.
population_specificity: Coral (G. columna) infected with ciliates.
effective_dosage: 500 ppm, 1500 ppm, 2500 ppm, 5000 ppm, 7500 ppm, and 10,000 ppm (1500 ppm was identified as the LC50).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of clove essential oil ointment (3%, w/w) with ketoconazole cream (2%, w/w) for treating Microsporum gallinae infection in chickens.
results_summary: Clove essential oil ointment reduced viable M. gallinae by 99.99% within 1 hour in vitro and showed noninferior therapeutic efficacy to ketoconazole cream in infected chickens, with 90% of animals fully recovered by day 35.
population_specificity: Chickens infected with Microsporum gallinae (avian dermatophytosis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of clove size on the growth and bulb yield of garlic (Allium sativum L.).
results_summary: Larger clove sizes (3-3.5 g) significantly reduced days to emergence and maturity while increasing total bulb yield by 25.88% and 15.58% compared to smaller clove sizes (1-1.49 g and 2-2.5 g). The treatment also improved most growth and bulb yield components.
population_specificity: Garlic plants (variety "Tseday") grown in a field experiment at Debre Berhan University.
study_duration: 2020/21 main cropping season (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop mucoadhesive bilayer films containing clove essential oil (CEO) and moxifloxacin hydrochloride to combat bacterial infections in periodontitis.
results_summary: The films demonstrated high antibacterial activity against both gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria, with excellent pharmaceutical attributes and sustained drug release for up to 48 hours.
population_specificity: Not specified (in-vitro study).
study_duration: Not specified (in-vitro release study lasted 48 hours).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of clove essential oil, alone and in combination with rosemary essential oil, on growth performance, immunological responses, hematological parameters, physiological responses, and antioxidant status in growing rabbits.
results_summary: The study found that clove essential oil supplementation improved red blood cell counts, hemoglobin levels, and antioxidant enzyme activity (catalase, superoxide dismutase, and glutathione peroxidase) but did not affect growth performance or immunological traits.
population_specificity: 42-day-old growing V-line rabbits (both sexes, initial weight 765 ± 6 g).
effective_dosage: 400 mg/kg diet (clove alone) or 200 mg/kg diet (clove in combination with rosemary).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sanitizing hatching eggs with clove essential oil affects broiler performance, hatch window, and embryo/chick quality.
results_summary: Clove essential oil did not negatively affect embryo or chick quality or broiler performance, though survivability during the initial rearing period (1-28 days) differed significantly among treatments.
population_specificity: Hatching eggs from 37-week-old broiler breeder hens (CPK lineage).
effective_dosage: Not specified (spraying with clove essential oil).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the chemical composition of clove essential oil and investigate its biological activities, including antibacterial, antioxidant, allelopathic, and insecticide effects.
results_summary: The study found that clove essential oil had significant antibacterial activity against Escherichia coli, strong antioxidant properties, allelopathic effects on Hyoscyamus niger seeds, and insecticidal effects against Sitophilus oryzae. The major compound identified was eugenol (68.7-87.4%).
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and insect/plant models).
effective_dosage: Not specified for human use; DL50 for insecticide effect was 252.4 μL/L air.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of clove oil in creating bioactive coatings for food packaging, focusing on antimicrobial and antioxidant properties.
results_summary: Clove oil formed stable emulsions with chitosan, leading to coatings with high radical scavenging activity and strong inhibition of bacterial growth (Listeria monocytogenes, Salmonella Typhimurium, Escherichia coli). The coatings also delayed food spoilage, particularly in cheese, and provided UV protection.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on materials, not human subjects).
study_duration: Not specified (emulsion stability observed over six months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a natural additive blend containing clove essential oil on carcass characteristics, meat quality, and antioxidant activity in steers.
results_summary: The blend did not significantly alter carcass characteristics but modified body composition and had quadratic effects on thawing/aging and cooking losses. Meat lightness and shear force showed linear effects at higher doses, but redness and yellowness remained largely unchanged.
population_specificity: Crossbred steers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antimicrobial activity of clove against food-borne pathogens and assess its organoleptic effects on meat.
results_summary: Clove exhibited strong antibacterial activity, with the highest inhibition zone (18 mm) against E. coli, and significantly reduced bacterial counts in treated meat compared to untreated samples. Organoleptic properties of clove-treated meat were deemed acceptable.
population_specificity: Spoilage food-borne pathogenic bacteria (E. coli and Enterococcus spp.) in meat.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of gaseous ozone treatment on reducing fungal decay in post-harvest garlic cloves inoculated with Fusarium proliferatum.
results_summary: Ozone treatment significantly reduced fungal decay in garlic without affecting its aromatic profile. The results suggest gaseous ozone is effective for containing fungal decay during garlic storage.
population_specificity: Post-harvest garlic cloves inoculated with Fusarium proliferatum strains F21 and F22.
effective_dosage: Continuous gaseous ozone flow (2.14 μg m-3) for 20 hours a day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential role of clove in anti-COVID-19 therapy, focusing on its antiviral, anti-inflammatory, and antithrombotic effects.
results_summary: The study discusses clove's traditional use for respiratory ailments and highlights its antiviral, anti-inflammatory, antithrombotic, immunostimulatory, and antibacterial properties, suggesting potential benefits for COVID-19 treatment. However, it is a review, not an experimental study, so direct efficacy results are not provided.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing literature)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antimicrobial and immune-modulatory effects of clove essential oil (EO) in treating acute experimental campylobacteriosis caused by C. jejuni.
results_summary: Clove EO reduced intestinal pathogen loads, improved clinical outcomes, and lessened inflammatory responses in infected mice compared to placebo. It also lowered proinflammatory cytokine concentrations in intestinal, extra-intestinal, and systemic tissues.
population_specificity: Microbiota-depleted interleukin-10 deficient (IL-10-/-) mice infected with C. jejuni.
study_duration: 4 days (starting on day 2 post-infection until day 6 post-infection).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the pain, tissue effects, and horn growth prevention of clove oil and isoeugenol injections versus hot-iron disbudding in calves.
results_summary: Clove oil (CLOV) caused intermediate pain reduction and tissue alterations (e.g., eyelid swelling), with some calves showing decreased mechanical nociceptive thresholds for up to 3 weeks. Isoeugenol (ISO) caused less pain and fewer side effects, but both CLOV and ISO prevented horn growth in only ~50% of cases.
population_specificity: Calves undergoing disbudding procedures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the growth inhibition effect of clove ethanol extract on rice sprig pathogens and compare its efficacy with other plant-sourced fungicides.
results_summary: Clove ethanol extract showed strong growth inhibition (up to 100%) against rice sprig pathogens, with an indoor toxicity measurement of 18.82 μg/mL. It provided 37.88% protection of Rhizoctonia solani viability in water emulsions, though less effective than gallnut.
population_specificity: Rice sprig pathogens (hyphae and cellular structures of fungi).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the pain-reducing efficacy of clove gel against lignocaine gel, ice, and betel leaf extract gel during intraoral injections in children.
results_summary: The clove gel group demonstrated high pain perception scores (WBFPRS) and equal SEM scores to betel leaf extract and ice, indicating comparable efficacy to these alternatives but less effective than lignocaine. The results were statistically significant.
population_specificity: 60 children aged 6-10 years requiring intraoral anesthesia.
effective_dosage: 4.7% clove gel applied topically for one minute.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of an active fraction from clove (AFC) on human colon cancer cell proliferation, apoptosis, and the PI3K/Akt/mTOR signaling pathway.
results_summary: AFC significantly inhibited HCT116 colon cancer cell proliferation and induced apoptosis in a dose-dependent manner, likely by inhibiting the PI3K/Akt/mTOR pathway. The effects were weakened when combined with IGF-Ⅰ, suggesting pathway involvement.
population_specificity: Human colon cancer HCT116 cells (in vitro study).
interactions: Interaction with insulin-like growth factor-Ⅰ (IGF-Ⅰ) noted.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and optimize a self-nanoemulsion drug delivery system (SENDDs) using clove oil loaded with naftifine (NF) to enhance antifungal and anti-inflammatory effects for treating tinea.
results_summary: The study found that clove oil (10-17%) combined with naftifine in SENDDs significantly improved antifungal and anti-inflammatory activity, with enhanced permeation and stability, and no or mild skin sensitivity. The optimized formulation showed superior performance compared to a commercial product.
population_specificity: Rats (ex vivo and in vivo models).
effective_dosage: 14% clove oil, 12.5 mg naftifine, Smix ratio 3:1.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of dietary clove seed supplementation on carcass characteristics, meat quality, and sensory attributes in broiler chickens.
results_summary: Clove seed inclusion (1-2%) improved water-holding capacity, cooking loss percentages, and meat tenderness compared to the control group, though higher levels (up to 6%) linearly decreased final body weight without significantly affecting carcass characteristics.
population_specificity: Ross 308 broiler chickens (240 day-old chicks).
effective_dosage: 0% (control), up to 6% clove seeds in diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of clove essential oil (CEO) on growth performance and oxidative/nitrosative stress biomarkers in broilers under heat stress.
results_summary: CEO at the middle dose (350 ppm) improved body weight, weight gain, and feed intake in heat-stressed broilers, though it did not affect feed conversion ratio. Both CEO and standard treatment (vitamin E) normalized oxidative/nitrosative biomarkers, with CEO showing potential as a synthetic antioxidant replacement.
population_specificity: Male broilers (Ross 308) under heat stress.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether incorporating clove essential oil (CEO) into chitosan films improves their physical, chemical, and antimicrobial properties for use as protective coatings on fresh-cut apples.
results_summary: The chitosan-CEO film (CH-CEO) enhanced mechanical strength, water vapor permeability, antioxidant activity, and antimicrobial performance. It slowed quality deterioration in preserved apple samples, particularly firmness and color, and reduced microbial counts.
population_specificity: Fresh-cut apple samples stored at ~1°C.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the antimicrobial effect of clove essential oil, both alone and in combination with other essential oils, against various human pathogens.
results_summary: The study found that clove essential oil (ECEO) exhibited antimicrobial activity against the tested microorganisms, while orange and bergamot oils alone did not. Combining clove oil with other oils enhanced its antimicrobial effect due to synergistic interactions.
population_specificity: In vitro study on microbial strains (Streptococcus pyogenes, Staphylococcus aureus, Shigella flexneri, Candida parapsilosis, Candida albicans, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Escherichia coli, Salmonella typhimurium, Haemophilus influenza).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antioxidant and anti-aging activities of Clove essential oil (CEO) in vivo, focusing on its effects on lifespan, health, and molecular pathways in C. elegans.
results_summary: Chronic CEO treatment significantly extended lifespan and improved health in C. elegans, demonstrating antioxidant activity by reducing ROS and inducing SOD-3 and GST-4 expression. CEO also promoted DAF-16/FOXO nuclear translocation and induced germ cell apoptosis in a DAF-16-dependent manner.
population_specificity: Nematode C. elegans (animal model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the antimicrobial activity of clove essential oil (EO) against Acinetobacter baumannii and Klebsiella pneumoniae, and its potential synergy with colistin.
results_summary: Clove EO demonstrated high antimicrobial activity and synergistic effects with colistin, reducing the MIC of colistin by 8- to 64-fold in resistant strains and showing strong activity in time-kill assays.
population_specificity: Bacterial strains (Acinetobacter baumannii and Klebsiella pneumoniae)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the bactericidal effects of clove oil and encapsulated atmospheric pressure plasma (EAP), individually and in combination, against Escherichia coli O157:H7 and Staphylococcus aureus, including their efficacy in inoculated beef jerky.
results_summary: Clove oil and EAP individually resulted in less than 3.0-log reductions of pathogens, but their combination achieved more than 7.5-log reductions. The synergistic effect was attributed to clove oil increasing bacterial susceptibility to EAP without altering clove oil's antibacterial properties.
population_specificity: In vitro bacterial cultures (E. coli O157:H7 and S. aureus) and inoculated beef jerky.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate nano topical delivery systems (nanoemulgel and nanofibers) to enhance the anti-inflammatory activity of clove essential oil.
results_summary: Both nanoemulgel and nanofibers demonstrated sustained skin permeation and superior anti-inflammatory effects compared to pure clove essential oil in a croton oil-induced mouse skin inflammation model, with nanofibers showing relatively higher efficacy. Histopathological and immunohistochemical examinations confirmed the anti-inflammatory activity.
population_specificity: Mouse model (croton oil-induced skin inflammation)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-inflammatory and wound healing potential of a clove oil emulsion in animal models.
results_summary: The clove oil emulsion demonstrated significant anti-inflammatory effects (40-60% reduction in paw swelling) and wound healing (95% wound contraction by day 16, comparable to positive controls). Histopathology showed accelerated healing with early granular tissue and collagen formation.
population_specificity: Female Wistar rats.
effective_dosage: 10% clove oil with 4% emulsifier (Montanov 202™) at a 1:0.4 ratio.
study_duration: Up to 16 days for wound healing, 180 minutes for anti-inflammatory effects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the combined antibacterial efficacy of clove with antibiotics and other plant extracts against multidrug-resistant Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
results_summary: Clove exhibited better antibacterial activity compared to eucalyptus and ginger, and synergistic interactions were found between clove and ceftazidime, reducing the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) against P. aeruginosa.
population_specificity: Clinical isolates and a reference strain (PA01) of Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of natural compounds, including Clove, in preventing and treating infections caused by multidrug-resistant microorganisms.
results_summary: The abstract highlights the growing importance of natural compounds like Clove in addressing multidrug-resistant infections but does not provide specific findings on Clove's effectiveness.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify medicinal plants, including clove, used in traditional Iranian medicine for treating cold and flu symptoms, focusing on their antiviral, expectorant, and immunostimulant properties.
results_summary: The study identified clove as one of the most important expectorant medicinal plants for cold and flu, but it did not provide specific data on its efficacy or mechanisms of action. The abstract suggests clove is traditionally used, but clinical evidence is not detailed.
population_specificity: Not specified (general reference to traditional use in Iran, China, and other Asian countries).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether olfactory training (OT) with clove and other scents could improve olfactory dysfunction in post-COVID-19 patients.
results_summary: The study found no objective improvement in olfactory test scores with OT, but subjective olfactory function improved significantly in the intervention group, and parosmia frequency was reduced.
population_specificity: Post-COVID-19 patients with olfactory dysfunction (25 participants per group).
effective_dosage: Sniffing clove scent for 5 minutes twice daily (as part of a 4-scent OT protocol).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether conditioned open-label placebos (COLPs) paired with clove oil scent could reduce opioid consumption and improve pain management in head and neck cancer patients post-surgery.
results_summary: The study hypothesizes that COLPs with clove oil scent, combined with standard multimodal analgesia, will reduce baseline opioid consumption by postoperative day 5 and improve long-term pain and opioid use outcomes over 6 months. Results are pending as the study is ongoing.
population_specificity: Patients with head and neck cancer undergoing surgery.
effective_dosage: Not specified (clove oil scent used as part of conditioning).
study_duration: 5 days of conditioning, with follow-up through 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of clove as a natural product with anticancer properties, given the limitations of conventional cancer treatments.
results_summary: The abstract highlights growing interest in clove's bioactive components for their anticancer characteristics, suggesting it as a promising alternative to conventional therapies. However, specific results regarding efficacy or mechanisms are not detailed.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the structural features of SARS-CoV-2 S protein, its role in pathogenesis, and its potential use in therapies and vaccines, not specifically focusing on clove.
results_summary: The study found that SARS-CoV-2 S protein's subunits and conformational states significantly affect viral pathogenesis and infectivity, with potential applications in therapies and vaccines, but did not directly assess clove's effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (literature review on SARS-CoV-2 S protein).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of a lozenge containing clove oil (10 mg) and turmeric extract (100 mg) against a traditional treatment for oral submucous fibrosis (OSMF).
results_summary: The study found significant clinical improvement in mouth opening and subjective symptoms (burning sensation/pain, tongue protrusion) in the group using the clove and turmeric lozenge compared to the traditional treatment group. The lozenge was deemed a safer, low-cost, and effective alternative.
population_specificity: 80 patients with group III OSMF (Khanna JN and Andrade NN classification).
effective_dosage: 10 mg clove oil + 100 mg turmeric extract, three times daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the current state of knowledge regarding the activities, applications, and recent research on eugenol (from clove) and its derivatives.
results_summary: The study found that eugenol exhibits antibacterial, antiviral, antifungal, anticancer, anti-inflammatory, and antioxidant properties, making it a potential component for therapeutic products. However, high concentrations can be toxic, with a safe dose identified as 2.5 mg/kg body weight.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing literature)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the pharmacological properties of eugenol (a major component of clove) and its effects on mitochondrial bioenergetics and glycolysis in human keratinocytes, with a focus on dental medicine applications.
results_summary: The study highlights eugenol's anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and anticarcinogenic properties, and provides preliminary data on its effects on mitochondrial bioenergetics and glycolysis in HaCaT keratinocytes, both alone and when incorporated into polyurethane nanostructures.
population_specificity: Human HaCaT keratinocytes (a cell line derived from human skin).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of topical eugenol nanoemulsion gel (derived from clove) in reducing pain from arteriovenous fistula (AVF) needling in hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: The study found that eugenol nanoemulsion gel significantly reduced AVF needling-related pain compared to placebo and no intervention, with the lowest pain score (3.29 ± 0.67) reported in the eugenol group. The highest pain score (5.03 ± 0.57) occurred in the no-intervention state.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing hemodialysis with AVF needling.
effective_dosage: 4% eugenol gel, applied as a fingertip unit around the needle insertion site.
study_duration: Single application, assessed immediately after puncture.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the skin depigmenting and antierythmetic effects of an emulgel containing Annona muricata L. fruit extract, comparing formulations with and without clove oil (8%) as a penetration enhancer.
results_summary: The study found that the formulation with clove oil (FB) showed a marked decrease in skin melanin compared to the formulation without clove oil (FA), while FA had greater effects on reducing skin erythema. Both test formulations significantly reduced melanin and erythema compared to the control.
population_specificity: 26 healthy female human volunteers
effective_dosage: 8% clove oil (as a penetration enhancer in FB formulation)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the prevalence of hookah use and initiation, including clove cigarettes, among incoming college students and identify predictors of hookah initiation.
results_summary: The study found that hookah users were more likely to use clove cigarettes, among other substances, but did not specifically evaluate clove's effects or safety. Alcohol and marijuana were the only substances predictive of hookah initiation.
population_specificity: Incoming first-year college students (N = 936, 50% female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and tolerability of clove extract in reducing alcohol-induced hangover symptoms compared to placebo.
results_summary: The study found that clove extract significantly reduced overall hangover symptom scores (42.5% vs 19.0%, P < 0.001) compared to placebo, with no reported drop-outs due to adverse events. However, the evidence was rated as very low quality due to methodological concerns and imprecision.
population_specificity: Healthy adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a standardized polyphenolic extract of clove buds (Clovinol) could reduce oxidative stress, inflammation, and hangover severity caused by acetaldehyde accumulation after binge drinking.
results_summary: Clovinol significantly reduced blood acetaldehyde levels, oxidative stress, lipid peroxidation, C-reactive protein, and interleukin-6 while increasing glutathione and superoxide dismutase. It also reduced hangover severity by 55.34% compared to placebo.
population_specificity: 16 male social drinkers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the pharmacological properties of zingerone, a compound related to eugenol from clove, and its role in treating various diseases.
results_summary: The abstract highlights zingerone's diverse pharmacological activities, including anti-inflammatory, antidiabetic, antimicrobial, and neuroprotective effects, but does not specifically address clove's effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of pharmacological properties, not a clinical study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether clove could be used as an alternative odorant to butanol-1 in olfactory testing for patients with chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS).
results_summary: The study found that clove, along with other odorants, produced olfactory results close to those of butanol-1, suggesting its potential as a substitute in odor threshold testing. Olfactory function improved significantly after FESS, with clove showing comparable efficacy to standard measures.
population_specificity: 40 patients with CRS without nasal polyposis.
effective_dosage: Not specified (used as an odorant in testing).
study_duration: Assessments were conducted preoperatively and at 1 and 3 months post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Eezpain spray, containing Clove Oil among other ingredients, in relieving pain from mild to moderate cases when applied topically to affected areas.
results_summary: The study found that Eezpain spray, which includes Clove Oil, demonstrated significant efficacy in relieving pain when applied locally to affected parts over 14 days. The formulation was effective in mild to moderate cases, though specific contributions of Clove Oil alone were not isolated.
population_specificity: 20 subjects (both male and female) with pain in knee and wrist joints, back of neck and shoulder, forearms, and lower back.
effective_dosage: Not specified (formulation included Gaultheria oil, Eucalyptus oil, Turpentine oil, Clove Oil, Menthol, and Camphor).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and morbidity of various medical therapies, including clove oil, for treating anal fissures compared to surgical and other non-surgical treatments.
results_summary: Clove oil was identified as one of the newer agents showing promise based on single studies, but it lacked comparison to more established medications. No significant adverse events or risks of incontinence were associated with clove oil in the reviewed RCTs.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic anal fissures, acute fissures, and fissures in children (excluding atypical fissures associated with inflammatory bowel disease, cancer, or anal infection).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize and evaluate zinc oxide nanoparticles (CM-ZnONPs) using Cnidium monnieri fruit extract for their antifungal activity against Candida albicans.
results_summary: CM-ZnONPs demonstrated significant antifungal activity with a zone of inhibition of 17.0 ± 0.8 mm against C. albicans and a minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) of 58.59 μg/mL. The nanoparticles showed stable performance and potential for treating superficial fungal infections.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on C. albicans).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-melanogenesis effect and mechanism of action of C. monnieri fructus extract (CMFE) in α-MSH-stimulated B16F10 cells.
results_summary: CMFE significantly reduced melanin production and cellular tyrosinase activity in α-MSH-stimulated B16F10 cells. It inhibited melanogenesis by promoting proteasomal degradation of tyrosinase through p38 activation, without significant cytotoxicity at tested concentrations.
population_specificity: α-MSH-stimulated B16F10 cells (a murine melanoma cell line).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential of clove oil as a chemical penetration enhancer (CPE) for transdermal drug delivery.
results_summary: The abstract mentions clove oil as a terpene-based penetration enhancer but does not provide specific efficacy data for clove alone. It highlights the broader category of terpenes and other novel compounds for improving drug absorption through the skin.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review, no specific population studied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to isolate endophytic fungi from Clubmoss (Lycopodium clavatum) and evaluate the drought stress-alleviating effects of an exopolysaccharide (EPS) derived from these fungi on rice seedlings.
results_summary: The study found that EPS from Colletotrichum alatae LCS1 significantly improved drought resistance in rice seedlings, increasing fresh weight, chlorophyll, proline, soluble sugar content, and antioxidant enzyme activity while reducing malondialdehyde levels. The optimal efficacy was observed at a 50 ppm dosage, with EPS production conditions optimized to yield 17.38 g/L.
population_specificity: Rice seedlings (Oryza sativa) under drought stress conditions.
effective_dosage: 20, 50, and 100 ppm of EPS applied to rice seedlings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the anti-allergic and anti-inflammatory effects of Cnidium monnieri (CM) as part of a herbal combination for treating atopic dermatitis (AD).
results_summary: CM suppressed β-hexosaminidase release and, in combination with other herbs, inhibited IL-8 and MCP-1 release. The herbal combination improved AD-like symptoms by regulating MAPK and JAK signaling pathways and reducing inflammatory cytokines.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and in vivo models used).
effective_dosage: Optimal proportion was SR∶AR∶CM = 1:2:1; doses included high (2×) and low (1×) concentrations.
